column2: The Acorn 32-bit were a generation of computers by Acorn Computers Ltd., which utilized the Advanced RISC Machines (ARM) architecture and ran on the RISC Operating System. The Amiga CD32 was a short-lived console, and the last platform developed by Commodore. Released in Europe on September 1993, the console fully utilized CD-based functions, used a Gamepad instead of a keyboard, was compatible with CDTV games, and was said to be the first 32-bit gaming console on the market. However, the console could not keep up with the capabilities of competing systems. As a result, the CD32 never made it to the North American market, and production was stopped on April 1994, while the company behind it went bankrupt.

The Apple II (stylized Apple ][) is a microcomputer released in June 1977 and the first big successful computer product by the Apple Computer Company. The Apple II was in many ways an upgraded of its predecessor, the Apple I.
There are 220 video games on Apple IIgs.      They were released between the years 1986 and 2024.   611 people from 154 developers and publishers are credited with these titles!

Games documented under the Arcade platform aren't so much released on a unified platform, but often custom-built standalone games. What Arcade games have in common is that they are meant to be played in a public space. The games are released as robust self-contained units containing both the screen, input (buttons, joysticks, etc.) and internal hard- and software to make it all work. Traditionally Arcade machines are coin-operated, but they can also be free of charge in public exhibitions or use other payment methods to initiate a game.

The Atari 2600 was released in September 1977 by Atari, Inc for $189.95 (inflation adjusted: $945.70 in 2023). Branded as the Atari Video Computer System (Atari VCS) from its release until November 1982, the VCS was bundled with two joystick controllers, a pair of paddle controllers, and a game cartridge (initially Combat and later Pac-Man).

The Atom is a 8-bit microcomputer created by Acorn Computers and marketed in the UK. The computer used the MOS Technology 6502 microprocessor and was intended for the home market.

The BBC Microcomputer System or BBC Micro is a series of computers designed by Acorn Computers for the British broadcaster BBC. The aim of the computer was to increase computer literacy in the UK. It was adopted by most schools in the country. The computers were based on the MOS Technology 6502 processor.

Channel F, short for Channel Fun, is a second generation video game console by Fairchild. Released in November 1976, the console was initially marketed as the "Video Entertainment System", but was rebranded to avoid confusion with Atari's Video Computer System. In 1979 all rights were sold to Zircon International. The console's production was discontinued in 1983 after the video game crash.

The ColecoVision is an 8-bit console of the second generation of consoles. It was released in August 1982 in North America and in Europe in 1983. The console was discontinued in 1985 when manufacturer Coleco withdrew from the video games market.
There are 30 video games on Commodore 128.      They were released between the years 1985 and 2024.   10 people from 23 developers and publishers are credited with these titles!

The Commodore 64 is an 8-bit micro computer and successor to the VIC-20. It holds the record of being the highest selling computer model of all time with between 12.5 and 17 million units sold between August 1982 and April 1994. The computer outsold all competitors in the US, was the second most sold computer in the UK, but failed to get a foothold in Japan and France.

The Commodore PET (later marketed as Commodore Business Machine) was a highly successful microcomputer launched in October 1977 by Commodore. The computer used a MOS Technology 6502 processor and saw many game releases due to its popularity which was only matched by the Apple II and TRS-80 at the time.

CP/M (Control Program/Monitor, or later Control Program for Microcomputers) is a computer operating system that made its debut in 1974. The OS ran on most mass market processors available at the time and was one of the more successful operating systems until being surpassed by DOS.
There are 4 video games on CreatiVision.      They were released between the years 1981 and 2024.   1 developers and publishers are credited with these titles!

The Dedicated console platform documents all games released as a standalone device. This means the game does not support the use of discs, cartridges, downloading or other media to be expanded with more games. Instead it plays just the game or games it's pre-programmed (or engineered) to play.

The Dedicated handheld platform documents all games released as a standalone device that's held in the player's hands while they play the game. This means the game does not support the use of discs, cartridges, downloading or other media to be expanded with more games. Instead it plays just the game or games it's pre-programmed (or engineered) to play. Dedicated handheld devices are well suited to play while traveling because they are compact and do not rely on external peripherals. They are typically battery-powered.

MS-DOS was a computer operating system by Microsoft Corporation. It was first released in 1981 in IBM PCs as PC DOS, but was soon licensed to IBM clone manufacturers as MS-DOS. The last retail release was version 6.2.2 in 1994, but the system was still under development as underlying part of the Windows platform until Windows ME in 2000. Because of the dominance of MS-DOS and IBM PC compatible hardware, it became the most widespread PC gaming platform until Microsoft's own Windows became the new dominant PC platform.

The Dragon 32 and Dragon 64 are 8-bit home computers released in August 1982 by Dragon Data. The computers were marketed in Europe and the US. The computer used a Motorola 6809E processor. The 32 and 64 numbers referred to the amount of RAM.

The Evercade is a British retro-gaming handheld system developed and manufactured by Blaze Entertainment. It runs ROM-based cartridges, displays on a 4:3 or 16:9 aspect ratio, and can be plugged into a television. It was created in response to gamers, who wanted to play obscure and underrated video games. In addition to a large library of computer and console games, as well as various collections, it also brings arcade games at home or on the go.

The Game Gear is an 8-bit handheld system, which features a 3.2 inch resolution (160 by 146 pixels) backlit screen, sporting 32 colors out of a vast 4,096 color palette. It is powered by six AA batteries. It was manufactured to compete with Nintendo’s Game Boy. A TV Tuner accessory was built into the hardware, so it could be played on a TV screen. There were also Gear-To-Gear cables made to allow for two-player gaming. The system was discontinued in 1997.

The Sega Genesis, known as the Mega Drive outside North America, is a 16-bit fourth-generation home video game console developed and sold by Sega. The Genesis was Sega's third console and the successor to the Master System. Sega released it in 1988 in Japan, and in 1989 in North America.

These games were typically released on floppy disks and required no operating system on an IBM compatible PC. Instead, the disk was inserted and the computer powered on, and it would boot directly into the game. As such the games did not need the typical OS DOS to be booted first.

The PC-6001 is a series of computer models by NEC, released both in Japan and the United States. The computer first entered the market in November 1981 and ran on a proprietary μPD780C-1 processor which was compatible with the Zilog Z80.

The PC-8000 is a line of computers by Japanese manufacturer NEC. The first model (PC-8001) was sold from September 1979 in Japan. Undercutting the export price of the popular US-made computers of the time (Apple II, Commodore PET, and TRS-80) combined with its native Katakana glyph support made it a big success in Japan. The computer used the NEC μPD780C-1 processor, which is compatible with the Zilog Z80.
The PC-88 or PC-8800 series, is a series of 8 and 16-bit microcomputers by Japanese manufacturer NEC. It was one of the dominant computer platforms in Japan until being replaced by NEC's PC-98.

Texas Instruments Programmable Calculators are a series of calculators that have gone through significant hardware changes since their introduction in 1975. The programmable nature of the machines made it possible to code simple games on them. With each generation their capability has become more and more complex. Initial models could generally only output numbers, either on a small display or printed. Later models feature a larger screens allowing graphing and even color graphics and thus also more complex games.

The TI-99/4 and TI-99/4A are two computers released by Texas Instruments in 1979 and 1981 respectively. It claims to be the first 16-bit home computer, based on the TMS9900 microprocessor. Unlike the primary competition at the time the computer used proprietary cartridges for data instead of floppy disks or cassette tapes.

The Toshiba Pasopia is a series of computers released by Toshiba in Japan during the 1980s. The computers run on a Z80 microprocessor and run their own two varieties of BASIC, T-BASIC, which is based on MS BASIC and Toshiba's own OA-BASIC. Later versions had an updated version called T-BASIC7

The TRS-80 was a highly successful microcomputer released in August 1977 by recently fused companies Tandy and Radio Shack. The computer used a Zilog Z80 processor and saw many game releases due to its popularity which was only matched by the Apple II and Commodore PET at the time.

The TRS-80 CoCo (Color Computer) was a successor to the TRS-80 computer. It was released in September 1980, and aside from featuring color graphics, drastically changed the hardware compared to its predecessor by switching to the Motorola 6809E processor.

The Commodore VIC-20 was a highly successful microcomputer launched in October 1980 in Japan and in 1981 in the rest of the world by Commodore as a successor to the Commodore PET. The computer used the same MOS Technology 6502 processor as the PET, but added color graphics, ROM and additional RAM memory. It sold over 2.5 million units which was more than 10 times the amount of PETs sold, which was already considerable at the time. The VIC-20 was later overshadowed by the even more successful Commodore 64.

The ZX Spectrum is an 8-bit micro computer developed and marketed by the UK company Sinclair Research. The computer was first released in the UK in April 1982, and launched in the US the year after and most of Europe in 1985. It is the successor the ZX81 The computer went on to be one of the best-selling British computers. Over five million units were sold. The production stopped in 1992.

The ZX81 is an 8-bit microcomputer by Sinclair Research. The computer was released in March 1981 in the UK. It uses the Zilog Z80 processor. It succeeded the ZX80 and had an introduction price of only £50 in kit form which made it a very attractive offer despite the computer not being very powerful. The computer went on to sell 1.5 million units which is 15 times as much as its predecessor. In 1982 the computer was succeeded by the even more successful ZX Spectrum.
